summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) prosecutors discussing strategy regarding a female subject (likely Ghislaine Maxwell) in the Epstein investigation. They debate her willingness to cooperate, the potential for charging her, and a planned meeting with a supervisor (Geoff) who appears bullish on the case.

persons.name: Geoff
persons.role: Supervisor/Chief in the U.S. Attorney's Office
persons.context: Mentioned as a supervisor (likely Geoffrey S. Berman, the U.S. Attorney at the time) who wants to meet and is described as sounding 'more bullish' on the case than expected.

events.title: Prosecutors Discuss Subject's Cooperation
events.description: Prosecutors exchange emails debating whether a female principal subject (likely Ghislaine Maxwell) would be willing to come in to speak, potentially under a proffer agreement, or to cooperate against others.

events.title: Planned Meeting with Supervisor Geoff
events.description: A meeting is scheduled for the afternoon with supervisor Geoff, who is described as sounding 'more bullish' on the case, indicating a need for 'expectations managing.'

locations: 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY (United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: The document reveals internal SDNY prosecutor discussions in August 2019 about a female 'principal subject' in the Epstein investigation, widely understood to be Ghislaine Maxwell.
Prosecutors note the subject's 'posture is different now that she is the principal subject' and that 'the chances of being charged have gone up.'
They consider reaching out to her counsel to discuss potential cooperation 'against others' or speaking under an 'innocence proffer.'
A supervisor named Geoff (likely U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman) is described as sounding 'more bullish' on the case than the email authors expected.
The correspondence shows the active and continuing nature of the investigation into Epstein's associates following his arrest and death.
